I used to think choices in FMV games were mostly decorative, but Road To Empress is a bit different. Mistakes can lead to death, and dying here becomes part of the experience. For the low price, I expected a lot less quality, but I was pleasantly surprised.
The game is stunning, not just the FMV scenes, but the music and menus as well, with a lot of attention to detail. The costumes and settings look absolutely beautiful, not unlike Chinese TV dramas, but thankfully without the 50+ episodes I've always struggled to commit to. 
You have to be online to play it, but I had no lag at all, everything ran smoothly without so much as a stutter.

While there are a few QTEs, they are incredibly simple, and the only other input the game asks of you is to click and decide what path to take, which allows you to be fully immersed in the story, and meanwhile, you even can enjoy some tea and a snack (preferably not poisoned).
While it was not short at all, I was sad it was over. Though many choices will lead to a bad ending, it's still engaging to try and plot your way to keep Wu Yuanzhao alive. I'm very much looking forward to the sequel.

This game is a trip. The visuals are stunning and the acting is pretty good, but the real fun comes from the choices you make. You make choices along the way, and many of them are dead ends in which you end up dying a grisly death. The scenes that play out are fun and over the top. It's not bad for what it is, but the marketing is misleading. It's presented as a "choices matter" type game with "100+ story branches," but in reality, it's a completely linear death collector with 2 endings (essentially depending on which love interest's route you choose at the end of the final chapter). It doesn't span the entire story of the main character becoming empress as the title would imply; it ends perhaps halfway there.

That said, if you approach it with proper expectations, the deaths are fun to collect, and the production quality is shockingly high for an FMV game. The story is frequently rushed, yet still engaging. It feels like clips were taken from a larger drama that are sometimes missing the proper context or development to hit like they should, as if this is promotional material for a CDrama that doesn't exist.

This all leaves me torn as the experience was entertaining, and I'd 100% watch this as a show, but I'm not sure I can even call this a game, more like a drama with quick time events.
